4428121/4380221/4462215.title: (no title)
4428121/4380221/4462215.text:
Tháinig Ciarraigheach go dtí an Éaglais ar a phaigh lae ag baint phrataí. Bhí sé ag dul go dtí an Aifreann maidin Lá Nodlaig. Bhí daoine bochta na sráide ag seasamh ag an droichead. Do bheannaigh an Ciarraigeach dóibh agus d'iarr sé ortha an raibh sé in am chun an Aifreann. "Ó" arsa na daoine "tá an Sagart Paróiste thíos ag an ngeata agus níl aon pingin againne chun cuir san mbosca.Chuaidh an Ciarraigeach síos agus cuir sé pingin san mbosca agus arsa sé leis an sagart."Is oth liom a Shagairt gur caill tú an náireGur báire an ngeata Lá Nodlaig na PáiseTá Luther agus Calvin ag briseadh a gcroí gáire'S daoine bochta an bhaile ag seasamh na sráide"



It is said that if you had a toothache and you put a frog into a mouth and left him there until "screeched three times you would be cured immediately. If you had a wart and if you would find a snail in the dew of the morning and put him on a black thorn bush until he would wither then to rub him to the wart it would die away.There is also a cure in the grass that people gather May night. if it is boiled in new milk. People say that if you let the vessel that the grass was in on the ground while drinking it...
(continues on next page)
4428121/4380221/4462215.school_info: School: An Teampoll Geal, Ceapach Chuinn

4649677/4645819/4659226.title: (no title)
4649677/4645819/4659226.text:
There was a respectable family lives in the county Roscommon who owned a large property. There were three brothers, and a sister who married the herd. After the marriage they removed to a different farm in another county county. They lived there for some years and had a family of two boys and a girl. After some time the lady dies and her brothers decided to take the three children who they reared. In due time when those two boys and girl frew up one boy became full manager for his uncle who was a solicitor and spent nearly all of his time in Dublin. This gentleman married a Dublin lady. This lady made different rules and sent the nephews to eat in the kitchen with the result of the two nephews went up to Kildare where they were engaged as reapers. When the Kildare boys heard that there Connaught men employed they said they would
(continues on next page)

4742076/4733208/4770153.title: Saol a Bhíodh ag Spailpín Fánach Fadó
4742076/4733208/4770153.text: Bhíos ag cainnt le Seán O Súilleabháin siopadóir, a comhnuigeann igCillabunáin, par- an Bunáin agus dubhairt sé liom nuair bhí sé ag tuilleamh págh an lae ag feirmeoir caogad blian ó shoin go mbíodh sé ag obair o'n a sé go dtí na deich san oidhche. Caitheadh sé eirighe ar a sé agus na ba do chur "ar fosuidheacht" mar bhíodh siad sa tuar ar feadh na h oídhche.Annsan gearradh sé beart easrach, agus beart aitinn agus bheireadh sé abhaile iad agus gheibheadh sé a bhreicfeást tímcheall a naoi. Tar éis a shuipéir bheith ithte aige bhí iacall air dul go dtí an scioból agus bheith ag bualadh arbhair go dtí na deich sa Gheimhreadh. Prátaí, arán, uaireannta, is bainne a bhíodh mar gnáth bídh aige acht nuair bhíodh spealadóir ag obair gheibheadh sé an tae.Agus bhí buachaill ó'n áit seo ar aimsir ar an dtaobh thuaidh de Neidín agus gidh go raibh sé óg buachaill láidir, a bheadh é agus i rith an t-Samhraidh dheineadh sé an spealadóireacht acht muga tae d'fháil sa tráthnóna. Dubhairt an fear san liom uair gur minic a chodaluigheadh sé san áit in  a mbíodh na ba in a luighe ar feadh na oidhche mar ní bhíodh a dhothain codlata aige ar dhul amac dó sa Samhradh.

4723845/4718180/4942654.title: (no title)
4723845/4718180/4942654.text:
It was on a Monday morn, The weather it being clear, When Maguire and Mc Caffrey Started for Dunleer.When they went to Collin GapNo work there they could find.Said Maguire to Mc Caffrey"We're far from Donaghmoyne".They returned home on Saturday night,Prepared and went to bed.When Ward arose next morning he said"I fear my boys are dead"."What had you done for cash my boys?I'm afraid that you were dry,For you both went off that morningAnd never said 'Good - bye'"."For cash we had plenty.On the road we met a friend;He put his hand into his pocketAnd some money he did lend".Now to conclude and finish
(continues on next page)

4723845/4718181/4942659.title: (no title)
4723845/4718181/4942659.text:
(continued from previous page)
I have no more to say.Maguire and McCaffreyFrom their master strayed away.They made a resolutionAnd to this day did agreeThat they would never go a-rovingExcept to Mullaghance.



Almost forty years ago, Tom Maguire and Owen McCaffrey went to the harvest in Meath. Tom Maguire of Aghadreenan and Owen McCaffrey of Tahlagh were employed by my grand-father. These men were of the same age and were companions. Owen McCaffrey is dead but Tom Maguire is still living. He is seventy three years of age now.
(continues on next page)

4922104/4852449/4948511.title: Tale of Tory Hill Men
4922104/4852449/4948511.text: It is related that a number of farm labourers (spailpi) from Tory Hill went to the small county potato dig.The farmer who employed them had always his own special men with whom the spailini should keep up.They awoke at dawn and cleaned the drills or ridges of weeds, stalks etc. They then went to breakfast and after breakfast returned to dig. When they ceased  work at night they had supper and were advised by the farmer to go to bed.Paddy Lysaght of Tory Hill slipped out before bedtime and returned shortly afterwards.When morning came the men arose very late because the man of the house had benn waiting for the dawn, whereas Paddy Lysaght had plastered the windows with cow dung in the dark of the previous night and so the dawnlight had not entered.

5008912/4966290/5106288.title: Collected from Mrs John Lynch
5008912/4966290/5106288.text: Collected from Mrs John Lynch   OldtownNavanHer present residence was built in 1840.Prior to that the family lived in a thatched house which is still used as an outhouse.Once when the Connaught harvesters were in the place the house went on fire.While the place was still smoking the monks from [?farnham] came to collect alms.Mrs Brew gave cheerfully of what she had. The holy man blessed the place and saw that it would never again be destroyed by fire.

4798769/4796968/5151102.title: Donnchadh Ó Súileabháin - File ó Leathanach
4798769/4796968/5151102.text:
Bhí sé shíos thar Corcaigh uair imeasg na gcabóg. Tháinig an lá ana-fhliuch. Chuadar isteach i dtig an fheirméara, agus ní raibh blúire ón teine acht stumpaí dhon aitinn glas agus bhí buachaill na mbó leathta ar an méid sin. Bhí Ó Suileabháin in aice an dorais go fliuch fuar ag féachaint timcheall agus do labhair sé"Tá móin i dtrínnse a dubhairt séAg tóin a' tighe agamDóthain Rí na ghrátaBó le díol ar cháirdeAgus lón ar linn an ghabhtair.Agus dá gcastaidhe sinn  go tabhairne an digheD'ólfaimís a sláinte"
(continues on next page)
4798769/4796968/5151102.school_info: School: A Cnoc Buí, Drom Dhá Liag

4798769/4797010/5151352.title: Art Ó Ceallaigh
4798769/4797010/5151352.text:
Lá dá rabhas-sa a d'freastal na  na slighe dhomChun tighe Airt Uí Cheallaig seadh casadh mé istoidhcheMar a bhuaras  tig follamh agus teine gan daoineDo shuidheas in a fothair ag leigint na slighe ormSAN  BÓ  LEÓRSiúd isteach Art agus é ar buile dháiriribhNíor dhein sé puinn stadaireacht, nuair  d'fhiofruig sé díom-saMhuire aililiú a dhuine cadé an cine ar díobh thúNó cad é an donas do sheól chun mo thighe thúSAN  BÓ  LEÓR
(continues on next page)
4798769/4797010/5151352.school_info: School: A Cnoc Buí, Drom Dhá Liag

4811624/4803364/5180405.title: Na Spailpíní
4811624/4803364/5180405.text: Fadó teigeadh gach fear go dtí paróiste eile ag baint prátaí. Núair a bhídís ag imteacht dá cluithce eadaig a tugaidis leó ceann acu i gcóir Dia Domnaig agus an ceann eile i gcóir  gach lá eile. Úair amháin núair a bhí fear ag dul go dtí áit eigean ag baint prátaí do thuit an oidche air agus é 'na aonar ar an mbóthar tar-éis tamall conaich sé ceithre sidh-óga agu comra acu.Núair a bhí an fear ag dul in aice leo cuadar síos tríd an talamh. Annsan d'feach an fear isteach sa comra agus conaich sé cailín deas isthig ann. Do tóg se amach an cailín agus tar-éis bliadain do phós sé í.Nóra Ní Cruadlaoith ó na h-athair

4921871/4897557/5192463.title: Local Place Names - Names of Fields
4921871/4897557/5192463.text:
(continued from previous page)
The Cherry field, The pond field, The high field, The lower field, The haggart field, The Narrow field The big field, The fieldeen, and The cross field belongs to my father.



At the potato time each year about 100 years ago there came from West Cork and Kerry several working men with spades.After Mass at Carrigtwohill each Sunday at that time these men were seen waiting to be hired by the farmers. They took what was called contracts
